p: The molecular mechanism of how SeACoV antagonizes the host innate immune response has been preliminarily studied. SeACoV interfered with the activity of IPS-1 and RIG-I to inhibit the phosphorylation and nuclear translocation of IRF3 to block IFN-Î² production ( Zhou et al., 2019b). In addition, SeACoV can induce apoptosis via caspase-dependent FasL and mitochondria-mediated apoptotic pathways ( Zhang et al., 2020). These studies provide insights into the comprehensive understanding of the interactions between SeACoV and susceptible hosts. A mouse infection model has been established for SeACoV with active viral replication in splenic dendritic cells, which suggests that SeACoV may be susceptible to rodents ( Yang et al., 2019b). In this study, mice exhibited only subclinical infection, and seem to be more susceptible by the intraperitoneal route, with modest replication in intestinal tissues and titers declining around 3 days post-infection ( Yang et al., 2019b).
